para.paratext: Under Georgia law, there is a rebuttable presumption that every person is presumed to be of sound mind and discretion.[1] Thus, a plea of “not guilty by reason of insanity” is slightly different than other types of affirmative defenses. “Insanity” is an affirmative defense used to rebut the presumption of sanity under O.C.G.A. § 16-2-3 or used when the jury is authorized to consider a verdict of “guilty but mentally ill” under O.C.G.A. § 17-7-131.[2] In either case, the defendant bears the burden of establishing his insanity by a preponderance of the evidence.[3]

In early cases, the defendant only had to overcome the presumption of sanity,[4] and, if he did so, the prosecution had to prove sanity beyond a reasonable doubt.[5] However, later cases placed the burden entirely on the defendant.[6] In Fields v. State,[7] the court said: “The presumption is that all men are sane and no burden of proof rests upon the State to establish this fact. The burden of proof is on the defendant to prove insanity and not on the State to prove sanity, as was stated in the requested charge.”

Likewise, in Carter v. State,[8] the court held that the prosecution could proceed on the presumption of sanity without introducing any positive evidence of sanity and that the jury could find the defendant sane even against substantial evidence of insanity introduced by the defendant.

Finally, in Grace v. State,[9] insanity was clearly made an affirmative defense. Therein, the court concluded that “the burden of proof of insanity was properly placed upon the appellant, and the trial court did not err in failing to instruct the jury that the state had the burden of proving his sanity.”[10] This law continues to be well-settled today.[11]

Because the presumption of sanity is only defeated after a jury finding of insanity, courts have held that the presumption of sanity generally prevails even after a commitment to a mental institution, if the accused has since been released from that institution.[12]

However, in Butler v. State,[13] the facts warranted a different result. There, the probate court adjudged defendant mentally ill and ordered involuntary treatment. Later that day, the defendant stabbed an officer to death on the way to a mental institution. The Georgia Supreme Court held that the defendant was entitled to a presumption of insanity at her murder trial based on the probate court's earlier finding of insanity.[14] Butler was later overruled by Durrence v. State,[15] which held that the defendant bore the burden of proving that he was insane at the time he committed murder, even though the defendant had previously been diagnosed with bipolar disorder and had been involuntarily hospitalized; bipolar disorder was not the equivalent of legal insanity, and the record contained no prior adjudication of insanity.

In Vanderpool v. State,[16] the defendant attempted to take the insanity presumption one step further by contending that one trial court's determination that he was insane at the time he committed a latter crime could be applied retro-actively so as to support a presumption that he was also insane when he committed earlier crimes. The Georgia Court of Appeals rejected this argument, clarifying that, under former O.C.G.A. § 24-4-21 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-14-21), a presumption of continuing insanity applies only to future acts of the defendant, not to past behavior.

Spivey v. State[17] involved a jury charge regarding a finding of “guilty but mentally ill.” O.C.G.A. § 17-7-131(c)(2) provides that a defendant may be found guilty but mentally ill if the jury “finds beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant is guilty of the crime charged and was mentally ill or mentally retarded at the time of the commission of the crime.” The trial judge charged the language of the statute, but the defendant contended that the jury charge was unconstitutionally burden shifting. The Georgia Supreme Court considered the federal cases and stated: “The statutory provision that such mental illness be proved beyond a reasonable doubt is not constitutionally infirm.” Thus, where a verdict of guilty but mentally ill is authorized, a court may properly charge that if the jurors find beyond a reasonable doubt that accused is guilty and was mentally ill at the time of the crime, they may return such a verdict.[18] This would essentially make mental illness under a finding of “guilty but mentally ill” an affirmative defense where the defendant must carry his burden of persuasion beyond a reasonable doubt, rather than by a preponderance of the evidence.[19]

However, in Keener v. State,[20] the Supreme Court explained that O.C.G.A. § 17-7-131 “places no burden on a defendant to prove that he is not mentally ill, or that he is guilty but mentally ill. The burden is on the state to prove that the defendant is guilty of the crime charged, including the requisite element of intent, beyond a reasonable doubt. The burden is on the defendant to prove he is not guilty by reason of insanity by a preponderance of the evidence.”[21]

The Georgia Supreme Court, however, has consistently upheld the exclusion of evidence of a defendant's diminished mental condition when offered to support any mental capacity defense other than insanity or incompetency to stand trial.[22]
Foster v. State, 283 Ga. 47, 656 S.E.2d 838 (2008).

A claim of “diminished capacity” may be treated differently, but the Georgia Court of Appeals has, at least once, lumped this claim within the same category of an insanity defense. Trammel v. Bradberry, 256 Ga. App. 412, 568 S.E.2d 715 (2002). The court did indirectly note that a claim of diminished capacity is not necessarily “an affirmative defense whereby the defendant admits or has proved against him the elements of the crime charged, but then raises a claim of justification or excuse. Rather, the defendant is straightforwardly denying the prosecution's claim that a requisite mental element was present at the time of the offense.”
See Pickle v. State, 280 Ga. App. 821, 827–828, 635 S.E.2d 197 (2006) (quoting State v. Mott, 187 Ariz. 536, 552, 931 P.2d 1046 (1997)); Simon v. State, 321 Ga. App. 1, 740 S.E.2d 819 (2013).

Handspike v. State, 203 Ga. 115, 45 S.E.2d 662 (1947). The Handspike case was specifically overruled in Brooks v. State, 247 Ga. 744, 279 S.E.2d 649 (1981), where the court made it clear that the jury could rely on the presumption of sanity alone.
See also Gilbert v. State, 235 Ga. 501, 220 S.E.2d 262 (1975); Kirk v. State, 252 Ga. 133, 311 S.E.2d 821 (1984).
Hobbs v. State, 8 Ga. App. 53, 68 S.E. 515 (1910).
See also Johnson v. State, 235 Ga. 486, 220 S.E.2d 448 (1975).
See Foster v. State, 283 Ga. 47, 48, 656 S.E.2d 838 (2008) (“A defendant claiming insanity has the burden of proving this affirmative defense by a preponderance of the evidence.”).
Durrence v. State, 287 Ga. 213, 695 S.E.2d 227 (2010).
Vanderpool v. State, 244 Ga. App. 804, 536 S.E.2d 821 (2000).

See e.g., Pittman v. State, 269 Ga. 419, 419, 499 S.E.2d 62 (1998), holding that where the defendant was convicted of malice murder after the trial court charged jury on “guilty but mentally ill,” the evidence was “sufficient to authorize a finding that [the defendant] failed to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that he was mentally ill or mentally retarded at the time of the homicide.”

See also Holder v. State, 194 Ga. App. 790, 793, 391 S.E.2d 808 (1990), explaining that “in charging the jury that they could arrive at a verdict of a guilty but mentally ill [the trial court] merely allowed for an accommodation to the mental health needs of the appellant who was alleged to be laboring under a mental illness which fell short of the legal defenses of insanity and delusional compulsion promulgated in O.C.G.A. §§ 16-3-2 and 16-3-3.”
But see Pittman v. State, 269 Ga. 419, 499 S.E.2d 62 (1998).
Followed by Boswell v. State, 275 Ga. 689, 572 S.E.2d 565 (2002).

In Torres v. State, 297 Ga. 32, 771 S.E.2d 894 (2015), the Supreme Court, rejected the argument that trial counsel was deficient when he failed to pursue a mental health defense, where instead the defendant argued at trial that he was not the perpetrator of the crimes. The Court opined that the mental health defense would have precluded the defense that he was not the perpetrator since a mental health defense would have necessitated the defendant admitting he had committed the criminal acts.
